key_points: Thirteen American troops were among nearly 200 people killed in an attack at the Kabul airport in Afghanistan.
The attack, executed by an ISIS-K suicide bomber, also claimed the lives of at least 170 Afghans, two Brits, and the child of a British citizen.
President Joe Biden described the U.S. service members killed as "heroes" engaged in a dangerous mission.
Among the American victims were 11 Marines, an Army soldier, and a Navy medic.
Adm. Mike Gilday hailed the service members' courage, citing their sacrifice as representative of American ideals.
Navy Corpsman Maxton Soviak, 22, recognized for his proud service and aspired to make the Navy a lifelong career.
Marine Corps Lance Cpl. David Espinoza, 20, was remembered for embodying American values like dedication and service.
Marine Corps Lance Cpl. Rylee McCollum, 20, was about to become a father, with a deep commitment to the Marines.
Marine Corps Lance Cpl. Kareem Nikoui, 20, had a lifelong aspiration to serve in the Marine Corps, according to his father.
Marine Corps Cpl. Hunter Lopez, 22, son of two sheriff's department members, planned to become a deputy post-deployment.
spokespersons: Adm. Mike Gilday (Chief of Naval Operations)
Rachel Soviak (Mother of Navy Corpsman Maxton Soviak)
Principal Armando Salazar (Principal, Lyndon B. Johnson High School)
Cheyenne McCollum (Sister of Marine Corps Lance Cpl. Rylee McCollum)
Jim McCollum (Father of Marine Corps Lance Cpl. Rylee McCollum)
Steve Nikoui (Father of Marine Corps Lance Cpl. Kareem Nikoui)
Sheriff Chad Bianco (Riverside County Sheriff's Department, California)
Linnae Knauss (Stepmother of Army Staff Sgt. Ryan Knauss)
Wayne Knauss (Grandfather of Army Staff Sgt. Ryan Knauss)
